title: Treating the Evil Twins of Chronic Pelvic Pain-Endometriosis and Interstitial Cystitis

content: Diana was a 40-year-old wife and mother embarking on a real estate career when her pelvic pain began. She woke up one morning feeling pressure in her bladder and burning pain when she used the bathroom. Weeks passed with no improvement in her symptoms––and no signs of infection or other causes. She was referred to a urologist who diagnosed her with painful bladder syndrome or interstitial cystitis (IC).

Diana’s pain continued to spread. As months passed, she developed rectal and vaginal burning, bloating, and cramps. The urologist sent Diana to gynecology to be checked for endometriosis, since many women with IC also have endometriosis. He referred to the two conditions as the “evil twins” of chronic pelvic pain. The gynecologist confirmed endometriosis.
Interstitial Cystitis and Endometriosis Are Nociplastic Pain Conditions

Interstitial cystitis and endometriosis fall into a category of pain called nociplastic pain. The term was only coined in 2016. Before this, only two categories of pain were recognized: tissue injury pain (i.e. bladder infection) and nerve pain (i.e. carpal tunnel syndrome).

content: Nociplastic pain arises when the healing from an injury, infection, or other problem in the body goes awry. Inflammation spreads to the nerves and disrupts the normal processing of pain signals. Over time, typically months, the nerves become abnormally sensitive to stimuli. Pain comes on faster and lasts longer. Even normal stimuli are reported to the brain as painful.
The three types of pain now recognized are:
Nociceptive. Pain from an injury and inflammation; example: bladder infection.
Neuropathic. Pain from nerve damage; example: carpal tunnel syndrome.
Nociplastic. Abnormal pain processing in the brain; example: interstitial cystitis.
Procedures and Surgeries Are Ineffective for Nociplastic Pain

Proper pain treatment depends on the pain type you have. With nociceptive pain, procedures work well. But if you have mainly nociplastic pain, procedures and surgeries don’t work because they don’t target the underlying problem. With this pain type, the issue lies within the nervous system, even though the pain is felt in an organ like the bladder.
Diana had mainly nociplastic pain. She underwent years of ineffective procedures and surgeries that worsened her pain and debilitated her more because they didn’t treat the source of her pain.

content: Think of it this way. You don’t put a cast on a paralyzed arm from a stroke because the cause of the injury isn’t in the arm; it’s in the brain. The same is true when treating nociplastic pain.
Checking for Nociplastic Pain With the Central Sensitization Inventory

The diagnosis of nociplastic pain is often missed because it doesn’t appear on any standard medical tests. Fortunately, a clinical tool called the central sensitization inventory (CSI) is fast, simple, and effective at detecting the condition. A score of 40 or higher on the CSI (within a range of 0 to 100) suggests a significant amount of symptoms are from nociplastic pain.

For example, Diana’s CSI score was 70, indicating she had mainly nociplastic pain. In my experience, when the CSI score is higher than 40, procedures and surgeries may not be helpful. They could, in fact, worsen symptoms. A mixed pain state is possible, where you have multiple pain types at the same time. The CSI clarifies the pain type.

sections.heading: Proper Treatment for Nociplastic Pain Is With the Biopsychosocial Approach
content: The right treatment for nociplastic pain is with the biopsychosocial approach, which addresses all the factors that affect nociplastic pain symptoms.
Bottom Line

Interstitial cystitis and endometriosis are nociplastic pain syndromes. Nociplastic pain arises when the healing from an injury or problem in the body goes wrong. The central sensitization inventory (CSI) is a simple and effective way to check for this pain type. If you are experiencing mainly nociplastic pain, procedures don’t work because they don’t target the underlying problem. Proper treatment is with the biopsychosocial approach.
bullets: Medical therapies reduce abnormal pain processing by the brain. Medications such as duloxetine, gabapentin, low-dose naltrexone, and melatonin; mindfulness-based therapies; and acupuncture.

Psychological therapies enable coping with difficult medical conditions (e.g., mindfulness-based stress reduction, cognitive behavioral therapy, and dialectical behavior therapy); care for mental health conditions, particularly depression and anxiety, that affect nociplastic pain.
Social factors affect nociplastic pain: managing stress, and support for any history of trauma and abuse.
